tn.ref: A good name
tn.text: AT: "A good reputation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: living people must take this to heart
tn.text: They need to consider what kind of name or reputation that they have and will leave behind when they die. AT: "those who are alive must think seriously about this."

tn.ref: sadness of face
tn.text: This refers to being sad. AT: "an experience that makes a person sad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: gladness of heart
tn.text: Here the word "heart" refers to a person's thoughts and emotions. Gladness describes the state of the emotions of being happy and peaceful. AT: "right thinking" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning
tn.text: AT: "Wise people think deeply about death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: but the heart of fools is in the house of feasting
tn.text: AT: "but foolish people think only about enjoying themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2: translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the house of mourning ... the house of feasting
tn.text: These phrases refer to what happens in these places.

tn.ref: to the rebuke of the wise
tn.text: AT: "when wise people rebuke you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: to listen to the song of fools
tn.text: AT: "to listen to fools sing"

tn.ref: like the crackling of thorns burning under a pot, so also is the laughter of fools
tn.text: The "laughter of fools" is compared to burning thorns that are loud but quickly burn out. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Extortion
tn.text: This refers to forcing someone to give money or other valuable items to another so that the other person does not harm him. It is considered wrong.

tn.ref: makes a wise man foolish
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "turns the wise man into a foolish man" or 2) "makes the advice of the wise man appear to be foolish advice."

tn.ref: corrupts the heart
tn.text: Here the word "heart" refers to the mind. AT: "ruins a person's ability to think and judge rightly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the people patient in spirit are better than the proud in spirit
tn.text: Here the word "spirit" refers to a person's attitude. AT: "patient people are better than proud people" or "a patient attitude is better than a prideful attitude" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Do not be quick to anger in your spirit
tn.text: AT: "Do not become angry quickly" or "Do not have a bad temper" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: anger resides in the hearts of fools
tn.text: Anger is compared to something that lives inside of foolish people. AT: "foolish people are full of anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Why were the days of old better than these?
tn.text: The person asks this question in order to complain about the present time. AT: "Things were better in the past than they are now" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: it is not because of wisdom that you ask this question
tn.text: The person making this statement is not comparing the present and past logically, but subjectively. AT: "if you were wise you would not ask this question" or "asking this question shows that you are not wise"

tn.ref: those who see the sun
tn.text: AT: "those who are alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the advantage of knowledge is that wisdom gives life
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) that the writer uses the words "knowledge" and "wisdom" to mean the same thing, or 2) "the advantage of knowing wisdom is that it gives life."

tn.ref: gives life to whoever has it
tn.text: "it" refers to wisdom. Knowledge and wisdom "gives life" in different ways. Choosing good investments, making good friends, choosing healthy life styles, living at peace with others are just some ways of how wisdom "gives life".

tn.ref: Who can straighten out anything he has made crooked?
tn.text: AT: "No one can straighten out anything he has made crooked." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: When times are good ... when times are bad
tn.text: "When good things happen ... when bad things happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: live happily in that good
tn.text: "be happy about those good things"

tn.ref: side by side
tn.text: "at the same time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: anything that is coming after him
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "anything that happens in the future" or 2) "anything that happens in the world after he dies" or 3) "anything that happens to him after he dies."

tn.ref: in spite of their righteousness
tn.text: "even though they are righteous"

tn.ref: self-righteous, wise in your own eyes
tn.text: righteous, wise in your own eyes** - These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Do not be self-righteous
tn.text: righteous** - "Do not think that you are more righteous than you actually are"

tn.ref: wise in your own eyes
tn.text: AT: "wise in your own opinion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Why should you destroy yourself?
tn.text: The writer uses this question to emphasize that being self-righteous destroys a person. AT: "There is no reason to destroy yourself." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why should you die before your time?
tn.text: "There is no reason for you to die sooner than you should." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: take hold of this wisdom
tn.text: "commit yourself to this wisdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: you should not let go of righteousness
tn.text: "you should not stop trying to be righteous" or "you should keep trying to be righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: will meet all his obligations
tn.text: "will do everything that God expects of him."

tn.ref: more than ten rulers in a city
tn.text: Wisdom is being compared to many city rulers. Wisdom can make a person more important than many city rulers.

tn.ref: does good and never sins
tn.text: AT: "does good works and does not sin"

tn.ref: every word that is spoken
tn.text: AT: "everything that people say" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: you know yourself
tn.text: "you yourself know." Here "yourself" is used to emphasize that "you know." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: in your own heart
tn.text: AT: "in your own thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: All this have I proven
tn.text: "All this that I have already wrote about have I proven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: it was more than I could be
tn.text: "it was beyond my ability to understand"

tn.ref: far off and very deep
tn.text: Wisdom was difficult to grasp. When there was understanding, it was very limited. It required deeper insight than the author was able to gain. AT: "difficult to understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Who can find it?
tn.text: The writer uses this question to emphasize the difficulty in understanding wisdom. AT: "No one can understand it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: I turned my heart
tn.text: Here the word "heart" refers to the mind. AT: "I turned my thoughts" or "I determined" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: any woman whose heart is full of snares and nets, and whose hands are chains
tn.text: The writer says that the seductive woman is like traps that hunters use to catch animals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: whose heart is full of snares and nets
tn.text: Here the word "heart" refers to the thoughts and emotions. This is a woman who is only interested in self gain. AT: "who wants to trap someone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: snares and nets
tn.text: These two words both refer to ways in which people trap animals. She continually thinks of ways to trap men into having to give her things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: whose hands are chains
tn.text: Here the word "hands" refers to power or control. AT: "from whom no one can escape" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the sinner will be taken by her
tn.text: AT: "she will capture the sinner" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: adding one discovery to another
tn.text: AT: "discovering one thing after another" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: in order to find an explanation of reality
tn.text: AT: "in order to be able to explain life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: one righteous man among a thousand
tn.text: Only one righteous man was found in a group of 1,000 men. AT: "1 righteous man among 1,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: a woman among all those
tn.text: There were no righteous women found in a group of 1,000 women.

tn.ref: they have gone away looking for many difficulties
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "they have made many sinful plans" or 2) "they have made their own lives difficult."

tn.ref: they have gone away
tn.text: Here the word "they" refers to "humanity."
